aging NAD+ nicotinamide mononucleotide pointâof care

passage.text: Fingerstick blood assay maps realâworld NAD + disparity across gender and age
Abstract

Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) level has been associated with various ageârelated diseases and its pharmacological modulation emerges as a potential approach for aging intervention. But human NAD+ landscape exhibits large heterogeneity. The lack of rapid, lowâcost assays limits the establishment of wholeâblood NAD+ baseline and the development of personalized therapies, especially for those with poor responses towards conventional NAD+ supplementations. Here, we developed an automated NAD+ analyzer for the rapid measurement of NAD+ with 5âÎ¼L of capillary blood using recombinant bioluminescent sensor protein and automated optical reader. The minimal invasiveness of the assay allowed a frequent and decentralized mapping of realâworld NAD+ dynamics. We showed that aerobic sport and NMN supplementation increased wholeâblood NAD+ and that male on average has higher NAD+ than female before the age of 50. We further revealed the longâterm stability of human NAD+ baseline over 100âdays and identified major realâworld NAD+âmodulating behaviors.

To facilitate the mapping of heterogeneous NAD+ landscape in human, we developed an automated NAD+ analyzer using bioluminescent sensor proteins for quantifying whole blood NAD+ levels from 5âÎ¼L of capillary blood. The comparison with LCâMS for measuring clinical samples established the analyzer as a reliable quantification method. The minimally invasive assay mapped the realâworld NAD+ dynamics associated with gender and age and revealed the realâworld NAD+âmodulating behaviors.
Abbreviations
BRET
Bioluminescence resonance energy transfer
ESI
Electrospray ionization
E. coli
Escherichia coli
HRR
Heart rate reserve
HPLC
Highâperformance liquid chromatography
IPTG
Isopropyl Î²âDâthiogalactopyranoside
LOD
Limit of detection
LOQ
Limit of quantification
LCâMS
Liquid chromatographyâmass spectrometry
NA
Niacin
NAM
Nicotinamide
NAD+
Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide
NMN
Nicotinamide mononucleotide
NR
Nicotinamide riboside
NMR
Nuclear magnetic resonance
PBMCs
Peripheral blood mononuclear cells
PPC
Phosphatidylcholine
PARPs
Poly(ADPâribose) polymerase
RFP
Red fluorescent protein
INTRODUCTION

NAD+ is an essential substrate for numerous redox reactions and regulatory proteins including poly(ADPâribose) polymerase (PARPs), Sirtuins, CD38/157 and SARMs, which play important roles in DNA repair, protein deacetylation, immune response, and other fundamental cellular processes (Chini et al.,Â ; Covarrubias et al.,Â ; Imai & Guarente,Â ; Katsyuba et al.,Â ; Rajman, Chwalek, & Sinclair,Â ). In blood, NAD+ is enriched in erythrocytes compared to serum and white blood cells (Chaleckis et al.,Â ; Chaleckis, Murakami, Takada, Kondoh, & Yanagida,Â ; Clement, Wong, Poljak, Sachdev, & Braidy,Â ). The decline of NAD+ content in blood cells (Chaleckis et al.,Â ), muscle (Zhang et al.,Â ), and saliva (Teruya, Goga, & Yanagida,Â ) has been associated with aging and ageârelated symptoms such as frailty (Covarrubias et al.,Â ; Kumar et al.,Â ), rheumatoid arthritis (Busso et al.,Â ; Weiqian, Caihong, & Jin,Â ), and heart failure (Carpenter & Dierickx,Â ; Yuan et al.,Â ) at old age. In addition, oral administration of NAD+ precursors as a potential intervention strategy of ageârelated symptoms has been demonstrated in clinical trials to improve body NAD+ levels (Chini et al.,Â ; Imai et al.,Â ; Khan et al.,Â ; Pirinen et al.,Â ; Rajman et al.,Â ; Yoshino, Baur, & Imai,Â ), muscle functions, and skeletal muscle insulin sensitivity and signaling (Goody & Henry,Â ; Yoshino et al.,Â ), establishing NAD+ level as an emerging indicator of healthy aging.

However, as considerable disparity exists in both the genoâ and phenotype of human aging, the blood NAD+ landscapes of different people and aging processes are yet to be fully characterized (Balashova et al.,Â ; Yang et al.,Â ). One major limitation for mapping the NAD+ landscape at the point of care is its quantification method. Conventional NAD+ measurement relies on HighâPerformance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) (Klaidman, Leung, & Adams,Â ; Yoshino & Imai,Â ), Liquid ChromatographyâMass Spectrometry (LCâMS) (Bustamante et al.,Â ; Giner et al.,Â ; Trammell & Brenner,Â ), enzyme cycling assays (Graeff & Lee,Â ) or Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) (de Graaf & Behar,Â ; Lu, Zhu, & Chen,Â ; Shabalin et al.,Â ), which requires centralized laboratories and multiâstep sample preparations. Recently developed semisynthetic bioluminescent sensors offered a solution for measuring NAD+ at pointâofâcare (Sallin et al.,Â ; Yu et al.,Â ). But this sensor relies on a synthetic chemical tether that requires multiâstep synthesis with relatively low yield, limiting its mass production. Hence, more costâeffective and easyâtoâproduce protein sensors should make the assay much more available and affordable for the largeâscale, realâworld mapping of NAD+ dynamics.

Here we developed an NAD+ assay using an Escherichia coli (E.coli)âproduced (Chen et al.,Â ), fully genetically encoded NAD+ sensor and a simple, automated deskâtop reader for measuring NAD+ levels in venous and capillary blood, as well as in saliva with 5âÎ¼L of the sample. We used this assay in a placeboâcontrolled, doubleâblind clinical trial to assess the effect of NMN and aerobic sport. We showed that oral NMN supplementation and aerobic sport can significantly increase wholeâblood NAD+ levels. In addition, the highâlevel agreement between the sensor and HPLCâMS established the sensor as a viable NAD+ quantification method. The assay further mapped the NAD+ levels in capillary blood and revealed a marked NAD+ disparity across gender and age. Moreover, the sensor made longâterm and frequent NAD+ monitoring easily available due to the minimal invasiveness of the capillary sampling, with which we mapped the speculated NAD+ circadian rhythm, shortâterm pharmacodynamics of oral NMN administration, and the longâterm realâworld NAD+ baseline in human.
RESULTS
Measuring blood NAD + using recombinant bioluminescent sensor protein

For achieving lowâcost and rapid NAD+ measurement in clinical samples, we developed an NAD+ assay using a simple, automated reader and a fully genetically encoded bioluminescent NAD+ sensor protein named NSâGoji 1.3. The recombinantly expressed sensor contains an engineered NAD+âbinding domain, a circularly permuted luciferase cpNLuc and a red fluorescent protein (RFP) mScarletâI (FigureÂ 1a). NSâGoji 1.3 undergoes considerable conformational changes upon NAD+ binding and shortens the distance between cpNLuc and mScarletâI, thus affecting the Bioluminescence Resonance Energy Transfer (BRET) efficiency between the pair (FigureÂ 1b). The highly specific NAD+âdependent shift of the sensor's emission intensity at 460ânm and 580ânm is used for quantifying the NAD+ levels in the samples (FigureÂ 1c, FigureÂ S1). To automatize the assay, we developed a reader that integrates a singleâchannel pipette robot, a photonâdetector, and a reagentâcontaining test strip. As the E. coli expression system makes the sensor production costâeffective and scalable, the NAD+ sensor is easily available for largeâscale sample analysis. In parallel, an HPLCâMS quantification procedure for NAD+ has been developed as the reference method in which NAD+ was identified by ion pair of 662.0/539.7 and 80.0âm/z and quantified by the intensity of ion 662.0âm/z (FigureÂ 1dâf).

Quantification of whole blood NAD+ by sensor and LCâMS. (a) Sensing mechanism of the recombinant bioluminescent NAD+ sensor protein NSâGoji 1.3: The sensor changes conformation as a function of NAD+ concentration, leading to changes in the BRET efficiency between luciferase NLuc and RFP mâScarlet I. (b) Sensor's emission spectra at various NAD+ concentrations. (c) Ratios between sensor's emission intensities at 580ânm and 460ânm plotted against various NAD+ concentrations. Values are given as meanâÂ±âSD of three independent measurements. (d) Sample preparation procedure for NAD+ analyzer and HPLCâMS quantification, partially created with BioRender.com. (e) HPLCâMS retention time and ionization intensity of ions pairs for NAD+ identification and quantification. (f) Calibration curve for NAD+ measurement by HPLCâMS.
Aerobic sports and oral NMN significantly increase venous NAD +

Using the analyzer, we quantified the NAD+ levels in venous blood obtained from clinical studies to evaluate the effect of nicotinamide mononucleotide (NMN) supplementation on subjects between 55 and 70âyears of age (TableÂ S1). The doubleâblinded clinical test compared one placebo group and two treatment groups using different dosages of NMN (500âmg/day and 1000âmg/day) (FigureÂ 2a, FigureÂ S2). After 30âdays of daily oral administration, venous blood was collected for assessing wholeâblood NAD+ content using both the sensor and HPLCâMS. In parallel, wholeâblood NMN and 2/4âPY were also analyzed by HPLCâMS. Whole blood samples were measured because NAD+ predominantly exists in blood cells instead of serum or plasma (Clement et al.,Â ; Seyedsadjadi et al.,Â ).

Measurement of venous NAD+ levels in clinical studies of NMN supplementation and aerobic sport. (a) Study design for evaluating effects of oral NMN supplementation. (b) Comparison of NAD+ levels measured by sensor protein and HPLCâMS. (c) BlandâAltman analysis for venous NAD+ measured by sensor and HPLCâMS. (d) Effect of oral NMN supplementation on venous NAD+ level. Daily supplementation of 500âmg (nâ=â19) and 1000âmg NMN (nâ=â22) for 1âmonth significantly increased the venous NAD+ concentration compared to the placebo group (nâ=â25). (e) Venous 2/4âPy concentrations measured from blood samples with daily supplementation of placebo (nâ=â25), 500âmg (nâ=â19) and 1000âmg NMN (nâ=â22) for 1âmonth. (f) Study design for evaluating effects of oral NMN supplementation in combination with moderate level of sport. (g) Comparison of NAD+ levels measured by sensor protein and HPLCâMS. (h) BlandâAltman analysis for venous NAD+ measured by sensor and HPLCâMS. (i) Effect of aerobic sport with oral NMN supplementation (nâ=â20) and aerobic sport alone (nâ=â21) on venous NAD+ level. In (b) and (g), values are given as meanâÂ±âSD of three independent measurements. In (d), (e) and (i), error bars represent SD of the respective group. Significance was determined using oneâway ANOVA analysis for (d) and (e), and tâtest for (i), * pâ<â0.05, ** pâ<â0.01, *** pâ<â0.001, **** pâ<â0.0001.

The comparison between NSâGoji 1.3 and HPLCâMS demonstrated a good agreement between the two methods with Pearson's râ=â0.992 (FigureÂ 2b,c). The measurement further revealed that both dosages of NMN significantly increased the venous NAD+ in a doseâdependent manner. The recorded average whole blood NAD+ level was 23.8âÂ±â5.5âÎ¼M in the placebo group, 41.7âÂ±â13.0âÎ¼M in the 500âmg/day group, and 58.8âÂ±â21.1âÎ¼M in the 1000âmg/day group (FigureÂ 2d). Notably, the variation of NAD+ level in the placebo group is smaller compared to that of the two treatment groups. The group treated with 1000âmg/day oral NMN featured a wide distribution of the whole blood NAD+ levels (CVâ=â35.9%), indicating the possible nonâresponses towards the NMN administration. We then performed bulk RNA sequencing for the peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) of four responders and nonâresponders from the 1000âmg/day group and mapped the expression levels of genes involved in NAD+ metabolism (FigureÂ S3). Responders featured a higher expression of NAD+âsynthesizing enzymes such as IDO2, NAPRT, NMNAT2 and NAMPT, as well as a nucleoside transporter SLC29A3; while nonâresponders have more expressions of NAD+âconsuming enzymes such as SIRT4, PARP14, CD38 and PARP2 etc. Interestingly, PAPR9, which regulates antiâviral activities and type I interferon production (Luo et al.,Â ; Xing et al.,Â ), was highly expressed in the PBMCs of NMNâresponders. We further showed that the whole blood 2/4âPY level increased significantly for the group administrated 1000âmg/day NMN (FigureÂ 2e) and that whole blood NAD+ correlated well with whole blood 2/4âPY but not with NMN (FigureÂ S4), indicating an upâregulated NAD+ catabolism and nicotinamide elimination. Subsequently, we evaluated the effect of aerobic sports on the venous NAD+ levels of the placeboâ and NMNâtreated (500âmg/day) subjects for 30âdays (FigureÂ 2f, FigureÂ S5, TableÂ S2). NSâGoji 1.3 achieved a similar level of quantification compared to HPLCâMS for measuring venous NAD+ with Pearson's râ=â0.985 (FigureÂ 2g,h). The group with aerobic sport and placebo featured an averaged whole blood NAD+ level of 33.18âÂ±â7.2âÎ¼M, while the group with aerobic sport and NMN showed an significantly increased whole blood NAD+ level of 55.48âÂ±â21.4âÎ¼M (FigureÂ 2i).

In addition to measuring NAD+ in blood, we explored the possibility of NAD+ measurement in saliva. Recent work for identifying salivary aging biomarkers revealed that salivary NAD+ decreases with age (Teruya et al.,Â ). We hence tested if the bioluminescent sensor could quantify NAD+ in salivary samples. The analysis performed in parallel with HPLCâMS demonstrated that the bioluminescent sensor is capable of testing salivary NAD+ with Pearson's râ=â0.999 (FigureÂ S6).

Overall, we showed that NSâGoji 1.3 sensor and the automated analyzer are viable tools for scalable and lowâcost measurements of NAD+. The cost comparison between bioluminescent sensor, NAD+/NADH assay kit and HPLCâMS is summarized in TableÂ S3. The clinical study further demonstrated that regular aerobic sports enhanced the NAD+ in both placeboâ and NMNâtreated subjects.
Fingerstick blood NAD + survey reveals genderâassociated differences in NAD + levels

For conventional NAD+ quantifications, venipuncture limits the frequency of NAD+ sampling due to invasiveness. By contrast, collecting fingerstick capillary blood by disposable lancet (FigureÂ 3a) would largely facilitate the dissemination of NAD+ measurement, which is now made possible by the bioluminescent sensor. To evaluate if fingertip blood is a representative sample source for quantifying NAD+, we compared the venous and fingerstick capillary blood obtained in parallel from 13 volunteers within 30âmin. The NAD+ measured from the two sample types showed a good correlation (Pearson's râ=â0.987) and are withinâÂ±â15% error (FigureÂ 3b and FigureÂ S7). In this test, NSâGoji 1.3 measurement typically requires 5âÎ¼L of fingertip blood, while by contrast, a single venipuncture collection requires several milliliters of sample.

Fingertip blood NAD+ measurement for mapping NAD+ disparity. (a) Procedures of taking fingerstick capillary blood for NAD+ measurement. (b) Comparison between NAD+ levels measured from fingertip and venous blood. The Black dashed line indicates yâ=âx, and the gray dashed line indicates Â±15% deviation from yâ=âx. (c) Study design for mapping fingertip blood NAD+ levels for healthy volunteers with different age and gender. (d) Female participants (nâ=â75) showed a significantly lower NAD+ level than males (nâ=â67) in this study. (e) 50â85 age group has significantly lower NAD+ levels than 18â50 age group for both male and female. The male has higher NAD+ level than female for 18â50 age group but not for the 50â85 age group. Significance was determined using tâtest for (d) and twoâway ANOVA analysis for (e), * pâ<â0.05, ** pâ<â0.01, **** pâ<â0.0001.

Using this fingerstick blood NAD+ assay, we further mapped the whole blood NAD+ levels of NAD+ supplementânaÃ¯ve people including 75 females and 67 males across different age groups (FigureÂ 3c and TableÂ S4). The crossâgender comparison indicated that females have on average a lower whole blood NAD+ level (27.2âÂ±â10.3âÎ¼M) compared to males (32.5âÂ±â16.3âÎ¼M, FigureÂ 3d). The survey further revealed that participants between 20 and 50âyears of age have significantly higher NAD+ content than those aged between 50 and 85 for both genders (FigureÂ 3e). Notably, the ageârelated NAD+ decline is more severe for males with the average NAD+ level decreased from 44.2âÂ±â18.9âÎ¼M to 25.9âÂ±â9.8âÎ¼M (pâ<â0.0001). While for females, the NAD+ content is decreased by a lesser extent from 32.7âÂ±â9.6âÎ¼M to 24.8âÂ±â9.6âÎ¼M with pâ<â0.05. Moreover, the genderârelated NAD+ disparity is more pronounced for participants younger than 50âyears of age, but not significant for those aged over 50 (FigureÂ 3e, TableÂ S4). Given that NAD+ is enriched in blood cells, the gender differences in the wholeâblood NAD+ level could be partially due to the different numbers and compositions of blood cells associated with sex. Interestingly, a few participants have particularly high NAD+ levels for the respective age group, indicating the existence of outliers whose NAD+ metabolism is markedly different. Further studies to identify the genetic and/or acquired factors for this high wholeâblood NAD+ level should provide more insight for developing new NAD+ modulating strategies.
Measuring realâworld NAD + dynamics using minimal capillary blood samples

NAD+ metabolism plays a central role in circadian rhythm. However, the hypothetical human NAD+ differences between day and night have not been recorded due to the difficulties of collecting venous blood after midnight. As fingertip blood assay is easily applicable at the bedside, we collected and measured the capillary blood NAD+ at 4âam and 10âam from nâ=â7 subjects (FigureÂ 4a). The measurement showed that the capillary NAD+ levels did not change significantly between 4âam at 10âam (from 36.0âÂ±â11.0âÎ¼M to 38.70âÂ±â11.1âÎ¼M, with pâ=â0.0735, FigureÂ 4b). To evaluate the potential fluctuations of whole blood NAD+ during the day, we further accessed the capillary NAD+ levels after oral administration of 300âmg of NMN during the day starting from 10âam. The NAD+ level significantly increased 60âmin after the NMN administration and returned quickly to the basal level at 120âmin (FigureÂ 4c). Apart from the short NMNâinduced perturbation, no significant changes were observed during the day, demonstrating the fast metabolism of NMN and the strong homeostasis of the NAD+ level. Circadian rhythm is regulated by NAD+ârelated pathways such as extraâ and intracellular NAMPT, as well as by other attributes such as energy metabolism and obesity (Park et al.,Â ). To capture the subtle diurnal NAD+ changes, measurement in separated blood components such PBMCs, erythrocytes and plasma would be necessary as cells with and without nucleus may be regulated differently. More stringent selection criteria would also be of interest to include subjects with similar metabolic profiles.

Monitoring realâworld NAD+ dynamics using capillary blood. (a) Study design for comparing capillary NAD+ levels at 4 and 10âam. (b) No significant difference in NAD+ level was observed for capillary blood samples obtained at 4 and 10âam. (nâ=â7, pâ=â0.0735), though the average NAD+ level increased from 36.00âÎ¼M to 38.69âÎ¼M. (c) Oral administration of 300âmg NMN induced shortâterm capillary NAD+ spike with significant increases recorded at 60âmin (nâ=â5, pâ=â0.0034). (d) Scheme for the longâterm monitoring of NAD+ levels. Events including sport, sleep shortage, medication, menstruation, and dietary supplementation were recorded through questionnaire. (e) NAD+ dynamics recorded for nâ=â6 participants over three months. F and M indicates female and male subjects respectively. (f) Distribution of fingerstick NAD+ levels during the longâterm monitoring. (g) Effects of events on NAD+ levels for each subject. NMN and sport significantly increased NAD+ levels for sub 3 and 6 respectively. Only days with single recorded event were considered, while days with more than one recorded event were excluded from the analysis. Significance was determined using tâtest for (c) and sub 4 & 6 in (g). Twoâway ANOVA analysis was used for significance determination for sub 1, 2, 3 and 5 in (g), * pâ<â0.05, **** pâ<â0.0001.

To further map the NAD+ fluctuations in the real world over long terms, we measured the NAD+ levels of nâ=â6 subjects twice a week over 100âdays and recorded major changes in dietary, sportive, and sleeping habits (FigureÂ 4d). The result showed that NAD+ levels were mostly stable during the 100âday monitoring (FigureÂ 4e,f), except for one participant who spontaneously started NMN administration which induced a notable increase in the capillary NAD+ level (from 32.9âÎ¼M to 47.3âÎ¼M with pâ<â0.0001). One subject exercised regularly (11 out of 25âdays on which NAD+ was measured), and the recorded NAD+ levels on days with sport were significantly higher than days without. However, the sportâinduced NAD+ increase was not observed for the subject with a low sport frequency (3 out of 24âdays of NAD+ measurement). Other recorded events such as sleep deprivation, menstruation, oral administration of phosphatidylcholine (PPC) and silibinin did not significantly affect the capillary NAD+ level (FigureÂ 4g).

Taken together, the capillary blood NAD+ measurement revealed significant NAD+ disparity across gender and age. The sensor also facilitated the realâworld observation of NAD+ modulation by dietary supplements and aerobic sport. We further demonstrated that individual NAD+ levels are relatively stable over a long period of time and continuous oral NMN administration and frequent physical exercise can boost NAD+ levels. This easyâtoâimplement NAD+ test for blood and saliva provided a useful tool for monitoring the effect of various NAD+ modulating strategies at the pointâofâcare.
DISCUSSION

Wholeâblood NAD+ level is becoming an important physiological parameter for evaluating NAD+ boosting strategies. Several previously reported clinical studies of NAD+ supplementation established that blood NAD+ content decreases with the progression of ageârelated diseases such as mitochondrial myopathy and rheumatoid arthritis (Lautrup et al.,Â ; Weiqian et al.,Â ). In addition, previous studies showed that oral supplementation of Niacin (NA) (Pirinen et al.,Â ), nicotinamide riboside (NR) (Airhart et al.,Â ; Conze et al.,Â ); Vreones et al.,Â or NMN (Okabe et al.,Â ; Yoshino et al.,Â ) can increase the blood NAD+ level and lead to beneficial outcomes. However, the conventional quantification based on HPLCâMS or enzymatic cycling assays are timeâ and laborâintensive due to a relatively low automation level, hence limiting the upâscale and generalization of the NAD+ blood test. Here, we demonstrate that the lowâcost and recombinantly expressed bioluminescent NAD+ sensor protein enables easyâtoâimplement assays for analyzing microliters of clinical samples with a good coherence compared to HPLCâMS.

The two doses (500âmg and 1000âmg per day) of oral NMN supplementation evaluated in this work can induce a significant increase in blood NAD+ level. However, considerable variation existed for the group supplemented with 1000âmg NMN per day, indicating the heterogeneity of NMN responses among the subjects. Recent work on the NAD+ flux indicated an ageârelated increase of CD38 and the resulting NAD+ consumption, contributing to the NAD+ decline during aging (McReynolds et al.,Â ). Here, the RNA sequencing of PBMCs from NMN nonâresponders indeed indicated a higher expression of NAD+ consuming enzymes including CD38 and PARPs. The existence of the nonâresponders may be due to the hyperâactivated NAD+ consumption pathways that degrade NMN and NAD+ as substrates. More detailed studies would be necessary to better characterize these subgroups and to enhance the response rate of NAD+ supplementation. To better achieve supplementation outcomes for the nonâresponders, NAD+ precursors and modulators of its consumption pathways may be used in combination, and the convenient NAD+ blood monitoring can help to evaluate the effect of the combo therapies. Using the NAD+ sensor, we also demonstrated that aerobic sports increased the NAD+ basal level from 23.8âÂ±â5.5âÎ¼M to 33.18âÂ±â7.2âÎ¼M among the participants, providing precursorâindependent alternatives for NAD+ modulation.

As considerable disparity exists during human aging, mapping, and characterizing various subgroups of the aging phenotype is key for achieving personalized aging intervention. However, collecting large numbers of clinical samples has been challenging for mapping the NAD+ metabolism among different populations. Here, the bioluminescent sensor enabled an easyâtoâimplement assay for quantifying NAD+ using fingertip blood at a muchâreduced cost compared to HPLCâMS. The NAD+ survey revealed a genderârelated NAD+ disparity which is especially pronounced before the age of 50. The survey also identified NAD+ supplementânaÃ¯ve individuals with particularly high NAD+ levels compared to their peers. As this assay is minimally invasive and costâeffective, future surveys at larger scales covering different geographic and ethnic groups may identify more naturally occurring cases with high NAD+ levels. Further studies to elucidate the underlying mechanisms should provide new exploitable strategies for NAD+ modulation and aging intervention.

Furthermore, we established that human NAD+ is generally stable over long periods of time, meanwhile NMN administration can induce notable spikes in NAD+ and may shift the original NAD+ homeostasis. The elevated NAD+ level can be maintained by the NMN administration, but a safe and effective NAD+ window induced by such intervention is yet to be determined. In addition, we observed that regular aerobic sport readily increases wholeâblood NAD+ levels though by a lesser extent than the NMN administration. Despite that no shortâterm adverse events were observed in neither our study nor other reported clinical studies of NMN administration (Irie et al.,Â ; Okabe et al.,Â ; Pencina et al.,Â ; Yi et al.,Â ), there was a clear increase of nicotinamide catabolites including 2/4âPY, a uremic toxin, and methylnicotinamide (Irie et al.,Â ; Okabe et al.,Â ), indicating a potential overload of nicotinamide after high doses of NMN supplementation. The longâterm downstream effects of these catabolites should be better characterized to avoid potential toxicity (PoljÅ¡ak et al.,Â ; Rajman et al.,Â ) as 2/4âPY were reported to have inhibitory effects on key enzymes such as PARPâ1 (Rutkowski et al.,Â ). Hence, establishing therapeutic windows for NAD+ supplementation should be important for the longâterm management of agingârelated symptoms.

Several limitations should be considered in our study. First, we recruited 76 females and 67 males for assessing the ageârelated NAD+ disparity. Even though the sample size is sufficient for evaluating the ageârelated decline of NAD+, having more participants would be beneficial for detecting the potential NAD+ differences between more refined age groups. As NAD+ is blood cellâenriched, additional assays for blood cell compositions and counts would help to interpret the ageâ and genderâassociated difference in the wholeâblood NAD+ level. Furthermore, NAD+ quantification in different blood cell types would provide a more comprehensive mapping of the NAD+ metabolism associated with age, gender, and diurnal metabolic fluctuations. Second, our longitudinal analysis showed that aerobic sport and NMN increases NAD+ for the tested individuals, but more data points and larger sample sizes will help to identify other NAD+âmodulating behaviors and establish new sportive or dietary regimes to enhance NAD+ during physiological aging. The analysis excluded the data points with more than one event recorded on the same day and did not analyze the combined effects of multiple events on the NAD+ level due to the limited data set. Combining NAD+ levels with more comprehensive and continuous data obtained by healthâmonitoring wearables such as smartwatches will provide deeper insights into how different daily behaviors and habits can influence NAD+ metabolism and provide new approaches for its active modulation. Third, the NAD+ survey indicated the existence of individuals with notably high NAD+ levels. However, we could not yet characterize the genetic or metabolic features of the individuals within the scope of this study. But the costâeffective NAD+ survey will enable the mapping of NAD+ at larger scales and lead to future investigations into the underlying mechanisms.

Overall, we demonstrated a lowâcost and easyâtoâuse assay using recombinant sensor protein and an automated optical reader for measuring fingertip blood NAD+ and revealed how parameters such as NAD+ supplementation, aerobic sport, gender, age, circadian rhythm etc., may contribute to the NAD+ disparity amongst people. The widely observed differences in human aging underline the necessity of developing easily available, minimally invasive, and lowâcost sensing tools for measuring aging biomarkers to identify meaningful subgroups of the aging phenotype and to empower personalized aging interventions through the quantitative monitoring of NAD+âmodulating regimes.
METHODS
Clinical subjects and samples

Study protocol for evaluating the effect of oral NMN supplementation and aerobic sports on human subjects have been reviewed and approved by the ethics committee of Guangzhou Sport University (ethics approval number: 2020 LCLLâ009, Registry Number ChiCTR2000040222) in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki. First, the study evaluates how different doses of NMN affect the whole blood NAD+ level. Then, the study compares the effect of aerobic sports with and without NMN supplementation on the whole blood NAD+. The study recruited participants between 55 and 70âyears of age. The exclusion criteria are (1) having hepatic and/or renal dysfunction, infectious diseases, cardiac dysfunction, and/or spinal dysfunction, (2) having chest pain or shortness of breath during sport, (3) having more than 3% changes of body weight within 2âmonths before the study, (4) having previously taken NA, NMN, nicotinamide (NAM), or other vitamins B3ârelated dietary supplements, (5) taking coffee or caffeineâcontaining drinks, (6) during pregnancy or lactation, (7) being mentally unfit to participate in the study. For the aerobic sport intervention, subjects participated in centralized aerobic sport for 40â60âmin, three times per week. For the first 2âweeks, the aerobic sport intensity was maintained between 40% to 59% of the heart rate reserve (HRR), then aerobic sport intensity was increased to 60% to 85% of the HRR. In addition, subjects participated in resistance training three times per week. For the dietary supplementation, subjects were grouped and tested in a doubleâblinded, placeboâcontrolled manner with three groups taking the placebo, 500âmg/day NMN, and 1000âmg/day NMN. The randomization was performed by the random number table method. The intervention of NMN administration is double blinded for both the subjects and investigators. The placebo used was mannitol powder contained in opaque capsules with the same weight and appearance. The administration of NMN was performed and registered between 9 and10âam. The venous blood samples were collected one day after the last NMN administration between 8 and 10âam without breakfast via phlebotomy and were collected in plastic blood collection tubes with EDTA as anticoagulant for analysis. The study sets the primary outcome as whole blood NAD+ measurement and secondary outcome as lifestyle assessment scale SFâ36, the result of which is not revealed in this work due to scope reasons. The sample size per group was determined to be 16 with significance levelâ=â0.05, powerâ=â0.8, treatment groupâ=â4, Mean under H0â=â25, Standard deviationâ=â5, minimal detectable effectâ=â4, superiority marginâ=â0.1. Considering the potential dropout, no less than 20 subjects were recruited for each group. The dropout and their reasons were indicated in the CONSORT flow chat.

The study protocol for evaluating fingertip blood NAD+ levels of human subjects have been reviewed and approved by the Institutional Review Board of Shenzhen Institute of Advanced Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences (ethics approval number: SIATâIRBâ210915âH0575) in accordance with the Declaration of Helsinki. Fingerstick sampling was performed to collect 5âÎ¼L of capillary blood using disposable fingerstick lancets (STERiLANCE Medical Inc.) for NAD+ measurement. The blood sampling time, administration of medication and/or dietary supplements, aerobic sport, sleep quality and menstruation have been recorded for data analysis with written consent of participants. The exclusion criteria are (1) being younger than 18âyears of age, and (2) having hemophobia or other symptoms hindering the fingerstick blood sampling.
Sensor preparation

The gene of the sensor NSâGoji 1.3 was constructed in a pET51b (+) vector for recombinant expression in E. coli (DE3). The E. coli (DE3) was cultured 1âL LB medium containing 50âÎ¼g/mL ampicillin at 37Â°C with a shaking rate of 220ârpm to reach an optical density of 0.6â0.8 at 600ânm. Then 0.5âmM isopropyl Î²âDâthiogalactopyranoside (IPTG) was added into the medium to induce sensor expression at 16Â°C for 16âh. The E. coli (DE3) was collected by centrifugation at 8000ârpm for 15âmin and the resulting pellet was suspended in 25âmM TrisâHCl buffer containing 500âmM NaCl and 20âmM imidazole at pHâ8.0 for lysis using highâpressure homogenizer at 4Â°C. The lysate was centrifuged at 13,000âg for 30âmin at 4Â°C and the resulting supernatant was filtrated by 0.22âÎ¼m syringe filters for purification by NiâNTA (Smart Lifesciences Lnc., China) and StrepâTactin (Smart Lifesciences Lnc., China) columns. The purified protein was desalted and exchanged into 50âmM HEPES buffer containing 50âmM NaCl (pHâ7.2) with an Amicon Ultraâ15 centrifugal filter (10âkDa MWCO, Merk Millipore Inc.). Protein concentration was measured by Bradford assay. The obtained protein solution was added into an equal volume of glycerol for longâterm storage at â80Â°C.
Blood sample measurement by NAD + sensor

Phlebotomy was performed to collect venous blood samples in plastic blood collection tubes with EDTA as anticoagulant. Fingerstick sampling was performed to collect capillary blood samples using disposable fingerstick lancets (STERiLANCE Medical Inc.). The blood samples were processed by the analyzer's automated sample handling program in which 5âÎ¼L of sample were lysed by mixing thoroughly with 4 volumes of 0.5âN perchloric acid. The lysate was then diluted by 10âfold in a buffer containing 500âmM HEPES, 500âmM NaCl at pHâ7.2. 10âÎ¼L of the resulting solution was then added into 90âÎ¼L of measurement buffer containing 0.5ânM sensor, 100âfold diluted furimazine, 50âmM HEPES and 50âmM NaCl at pHâ7.2, which was previously lyophilized and automatically reconstituted in the analyzer's mixing well by the liquid handler. The sensor's bioluminescent signal was measured using the integrated photonâdetector (Hamamatsu Photonics) of the analyzer with NLuc emission measured at 460ânm (bandwidth 30ânm) and RFP emission was measured at 580ânm (bandwidth 20ânm). The sensors' emission ratio (R) between 580ânm and 460ânm was used to calculate the NAD+ concentrations according to the titration curve.

To titrate the senor, standard aqueous NAD+ solutions with known concentrations were prepared and measured by the aboveâmentioned method. The sensors' emission ratio (R) was plotted against the NAD+ concentrations and the resulting curve was fitted to the HillâLangmuir equation to obtain the sensor's maximum ratio (Rmax), minimum ratio (Rmin), c50 and Hill coefficient (h) NAD + concentrations in unknown samples were calculated with the rearranged the equation:
Blood sample measurement by HPLCâMS

5âÎ¼L of whole blood was taken from blood collection tubes and added into 20âÎ¼L of 0.5âN perchloric acid with thorough mixing. Cell debris and aggregates were separated by centrifugation at 12000âg for 5âmin at 4Â°C. The supernatant was transferred into sample tubes and stored at â80Â°C until analysis. Upon analysis, the supernatant was diluted by 10âfold in aqueous solution with 50% methanol and 50% water and then filtered with a PTFE syringe filter (0.45âÎ¼m * 13âmm) before injection into LCâMS.

Agilent Infinity Lab LC/MSD iQ G6160A was used to perform the LCâMS quantification of the blood samples. 10âÎ¼L of each prepared sample were injected into LC and separated by a ZORBAX SBâAq Column (Agilent, 4.6 Ãâ100âmm, 3.5âÎ¼m). The autosampler temperature was set to 4Â°C and the column temperature was set to 20Â°C. The following elution program was used: Aâ=âaqueous 0.1% formic acidâwater, Bâ=âacetonitrile, 0âmin 20% A, 0.5âmin 20% A, 1.2âmin 60% A, 2.5âmin 60% A, 2.6âmin 20% A, 3âmin 20% A, with total run time of 3.0âmin and a flow rate of 1.00âmL/min. NAD+, 2/4âPY and NMN featured a retention time of 1.09âmin, 1.15âmin and 1.06âmin respectively. For MS quantification, MS was equipped with electrospray ionization (ESI) ion source and operates in both positive and negative ion mode. Samples were ionized under highâflow conditions with curtain gasâ=â35âpsi, collision gasâ=ââhighâ, cataclastic voltageâ=â100âV, capillary voltageâ=â3500âV, and dry temperatureâ=â325Â°C. The following ion pairs were used for analyte identification: NAD+1: 662âââ539.7âm/z; NAD+2: 662âââ80âm/z; 2/4âPY1: 152.9âââ136âm/z; 2/4âPY2: 152.9âââ108âm/z; NMN1: 335âââ122.8âm/z; NMN2: 335âââ97âm/z. Standard solutions with known concentrations of NAD+ (0.07537, 0.1507, 0.3015, 0.7537, 1.507âÎ¼mol/L), 2/4âPY (0.3286, 0.6572, 1.314, 3.286, 6.572âÎ¼mol/L), and NMN (0.1496, 0.2992, 0.5984, 1.496, 2.992âÎ¼mol/L) have been prepared and automatically injected with single injections for LCâMS analysis to optimize the quantification conditions. A linear regression was then applied (weighting 1/x, rNAD+â=â0.9998, r2/4âPYâ=â0.9964, rNMNâ=â0.9994) to obtain the respective standard curves. The limit of detection (LOD) of NAD+, 2/4âPY and NMN was 0.0301âÎ¼mol/L, 0.131âÎ¼mol/L and 0.0598âÎ¼mol/L (Signal/Noise â¥3) and the limit of quantification (LOQ) was 0.0754âÎ¼mol/L, 0.329âÎ¼mol/L, 0.150âÎ¼mol/L (Signal/Noise â¥10). All calculation was performed with Agilent OpenLab Data Analysis 2.205.7.2 software.
Determination of recovery rate and sample stability

100âÎ¼L of solution was taken from lysed blood samples with known NAD+ concentrations. The samples were then added with 100, 400, and 700âÎ¼g/L standard NAD+. The samples were further diluted in aqueous solution with 50% methanol and 50% water for six parallel LCâMS measurements.

Blood samples lysed with 0.5âN perchloric acid were stored at room temperature and at 4Â°C for 0âh, 1âh, 2âh, 4âh, 6âh, 12âh, 24âh, and 48âh before LCâMS measurement using the aboveâmentioned method (FigureÂ S8).
Salivary sample measurement

Salivary samples were collected in 10âmL conical tubes in the morning before breakfast after at least 8âh of fasting, which were then added with various concentrations of NAD+ solutions to prepare spiked salivary samples. The resulting samples were loaded into the NAD+ analyzer and were automatically added with 4 volumes of 0.5âN perchloric acid. The analyzer then dilutes the resulting mixture by 10âfold in a buffer containing 500âmM HEPES, 500âmM NaCl at pHâ7.2, and transfers 10âÎ¼L of the resulting solution into 90âÎ¼L of measurement buffer containing 0.5ânM sensor, 100âfold diluted furimazine, 50âmM HEPES, 50âmM NaCl at pHâ7.2 for bioluminescent measurement. The sensor's bioluminescent signal was measured using the analyzer's integrated photonâdetector (Hamamatsu Photonics) with NLuc emission measured at 460ânm (bandwidth 30ânm) and RFP emission was measured at 580ânm (bandwidth 20ânm). The sensors' emission ratio (R) between 580ânm and 460ânm was used to calculate the NAD+ concentrations according to the titration curve performed in parallel. HPLCâMS measurement of the supernatant was performed in parallel according to the aboveâmentioned method as reference.
RNA sequencing of PBMCs

Around 10âmL of intravenous blood was collected in EDTA tubes at 10âam from four subjects with the highest and lowest whole blood NAD+ levels after 1000âmg/day NMN supplementation. The PBMCs layer was collected after centrifugation with Ficoll media at 400âg for 30âmin and then washed twice with PBS at 300âg for 10âmin at 25Â°C. The pellet was resuspended with 5 volumes of ACK lysis buffer to lyse red blood cells and then centrifuged at 500âg for 5âmin. The PBMCs were then resuspended in RPM1640 medium containing 10% FBS for cell counting and centrifuged and flashâfrozen for RNA extraction and sequencing.
Statistics

All values were expressed as meanâÂ±âstandard deviation. Statistics were performed using Prism 8 (Graphpad). All quantification tests were independently performed for at least three times. Data were represented as the meanâÂ±âSD. Correlations between two variables were tested with Pearson correlation coefficient. Levels of agreement were evaluated using BlandâAltman analysis. Significance was determined using tâtest, oneâway ANOVA analysis, or twoâway ANOVA analysis. * pâ<â0.05, ** pâ<â0.01, *** pâ<â0.001, **** pâ<â0.0001 throughout the manuscript.
AUTHOR CONTRIBUTIONS

Q.Y., M.H., and L.C. conceived the study. L.C. and P.W. prepared the sensor. P.W., L.C., and Y.H. performed sensor qualifications. M.C. performed HPLCâMS quantifications. M.H. and J.L. provided clinical samples. R.L. contributed to the sample collection. All authors contributed to data analysis or manuscript writing.
